comments.commentBody: In the 19th century, corporations were required to be organized for a specific purpose (like "build this bridge" or "operate this railroad"), not just "make money".  We should go back to that system of law.

Let’s simplify and ask not how big or small a govt? Let's ask, in democracy, how big or small corporate governance? How much influence should wealth monopolies have on an elected president/congress & independent supreme court?

To answer, let’s compare our past generations, with less corporate dominance on election campaigns and law writing. What were our living standards, business profits and equality, etc? Less extremism, and the Dems were an opposition party.
Then the # of lobbyists started to soar.
Corporate governance has so infiltrated politics, they set standards, agendas, terms of debate, before any candidates are even nominated. Media pundits have to argue on their terms. We wait to find out who the big money chooses for nominees.

Candidates are self selected from those who fit prevailing norms set by those who pay for campaigns. Those not in sync would choose other professions, or try to influence policy from outside the power structure, not in it. Applies to media, such as the Times.

Let’s research countries with economic rule of law, where business is profitable and where socio economic equality is reasonably high. If find both, analyze the relative size/power of business & govt.

Since the invention of the telegraph we’ve had some communication with nations across the ocean. Why not study them?
Shouldn't be too hard for some university economics/politics scholar to research this, and publicize his/her findings. Say in a Times column?

It is a singular matter that Mr. Corker is perhaps the most reasonable of the Republicans in the Senate--and he is very unreasonable. Most of the Republicans haven't read the agreement with Iran, and most of those who might have read it don't understand it.

Tonight Energy Secretary Moniz, himself a Ph.D. nuclear scientist, gave one of the most cogent reports on the Iran agreement on the Rachel Maddow Show. It was patently clear that this agreement is brutally stringent on Iran. It embodies, in fact, the most stringent inspections regime in history.

However, it doesn't do the impossible--it doesn't completely dismantle Iran's 40 year old nuclear program.

Why? Because Iran is signatory to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT) that gives them the "inalienable right" to peaceful nuclear development. Iran has compromised, but it is too much to ask Iran to humiliate itself by giving up its treaty rights. Iranians have an enormous amount of pride in their scientific and engineering skills. Iran would be the only nation out of 200+ NPT signatories to be forced to totally give up its nuclear technology. It is simply too much to ask.

However indifferent the Republicans might be to the reality of the Iranian situation, they are sure of one bit of humiliation they want to inflict--that is humiliation heaped on President Obama. No deal would ever be good enough for them. They want to see President Obama brought low and ground in the dust--more than they wish this for Iran.
Construction? Corker et al. seem bent on quite the opposite when it comes to our agreement with Iran.

Who knows maybe Corker is a genuine Senator who understands having working relationships with others regardless of party affiliation will result in better outcomes for all Americans.

I will say this, as a construction business owner myself you understand that ideology and political affiliation matter nothing when it comes to getting the building finished. If that is his background, I suspect the president will find a true working partner.
Anyone else remember how much the GOP used to love Dick Cheney's "Unitary Theory of the Executive"?

As I commented in an earlier version of this story, the police are doing themselves no favors by pressuring post-secondary schools and universities to, in effect, self-censor speech. It tells these young adults that, no matter what they think or what the Constitution they're expected to respect says, law enforcement is having the last word. Not exactly a ringing endorsement of trust in the next generation's ability to discriminate between speech, writing, and advocacy. And this at a time when law enforcement could definitely exercise some trust-building in the communities they police.

There was a time when schools would never have allowed themselves to be coerced or pushed around by law enforcement like this, and for a 15-yr old lyric no less! You'd have thought Common wrote a treatise lauding the entire Black Panther agenda, judging from the knee-jerk reaction to (and apparently comprehensive monitoring of) Keane's choice of commencement speaker.

This could've been done differently, and more respectfully, than going into the executive suite and demanding a change. Or else what? I wonder what would've happened had the school administration shown some spine and refused. How about some information tables at the speech, showing students how they felt about Ms Shakur and why? Instead, we have another needless demonstration by cops that the public-and students- are just an inconvenience to be ridden roughshod over.

I thought it was a very good episode. Ken's character evolved.  Death--whether literal or metaphorical--has been part of the series from the start.  Don is an embodiment of the America Dream: great looking on the outside, hollowed out on the inside.  (All that's left is the materialism. Equality, justice, fair play--died.)
Yes he can. The President is Commander in Chief and doesnt need to attack anyone no matter if Congress declares War. Which they won't.
And what a square!  After his tryst with Di he comes back in combing his greased-back hair like the Fonz.  Ayyyyyyyy!!!
Good deals don't sell themselves. No deals sell themselves. Welcome to the 21st century.

See someone's comment way above.  I can't recall much about my college reading of volume one of the trilogy except that it was written in the early part of the great depression, was more episodic in a newspaper-like fashion, and that Dos Passos was a leftwing author.
It's the hard that makes it great!  (paraphrasing Tom Hanks in "A League of Their Own")

You can stream the first episode of Wolf Hall for free whenever you like (until May 3rd) via PBS online: http://video.pbs.org/video/2365457013/ There are also additionally a few background shorts. (To watch it on my Apple TV, I had to type "Wolf Hall" into the search engine on the PBS site that comes with Apple, in order to find it - along with some previews and shorts. And once there you have to scroll down through links to the trailers to find the first full episode. Small matter, but wouldn't want anyone to miss finding it. The episode comes up immediately, of course, using the above link on any other device.) Cheers! And huge thanks, PBS, from one who happily cut the cable years ago.
How about Ken?  He had conflict inside and out in this episode.

Whatever the outcome our congress has really let the people of our country down. Corker's campaign against Ford showed what he was ready to do to win. The shameful scene we saw when Bibi spoke to congress was not enough now the fate of deal and the world my rest on Bob Corker! For the prime minister of a foreign country to publically say he was going to lobby us.  Corker is doing an end run around the deal. With 47 already on record to kill the deal who is he trying to fool? Sure he didn't sign the letter to Iran. Does anyone remember the white woman that just happened to be in his campaign ad against Ford when he ran for the Senate? Now Corker is the great statesman? If congress has approve anything the deal is dead and everybody knows it. Not because of the merits of the deal but because our congress is bought and paid for. Before there was even a deal they made it perfectly clear that any deal was a bad deal. Would we demand any deal with Saudi Arabia be contingent on them stop paying for the schools that teach radical Islam? We would stop selling them arms if they refused to allow females to drive? On our march to war with Saddam where was all of these statesman?  Everyone forgets when they say can we trust Iran that our CIA overthrow the government in Iran and installed the Shah. We seem to forget that any deal has to be sold in Iran too. They capitulated on this deal but they also have to sell it at home. They are a proud people their hardliners need to save face also.
That was Alexis Bledsoe from Gilmore Girls and Traveling Pants movies.
Wouldn't think that will happen based on the animosity between them in the elevator.

Maybe the tears in his eyes watching Bert's farewell dance and at Rachel's shiva suggest his frozen heart is beginning to melt.  (I said after episode 7 that he looked like the cartoon Grinch when he realizes the true meaning of Christmas; after tonight's teary-eyed shot, I'm standing by that comparison. :)

Of course, perhaps by now Mr. Obama has learned to use all levels of power to keep his office and the country from being undermined by Congress; In this case Senators that, without care about the separation of powers, sink the United States to banana republic status in the world stage --a chaotic ex-superpower unable of the most basic projection of power: that of being a negotiating partner among its rivals and even its peers.

But perhaps the dear Senator forgets that this treaty is not solely between the United States and Iran, but between Iran and the major Western powers, China, and Russia. Thus the treaty should be signed and enforced via the United Nations, with the US one country among many. If Mr. Corker has a problem with that, I suppose he should be prepared to impeach the President and remove the US from the United Nations, leaving our country an island of international opprobrium and isolation.

And, Senator Corker, while you are at it, as you say war is the alternative, are you preparing a military draft and volunteering your grandchildren to do war in Iran?

Frank, how can you say this is pablum for the massea?! The masses would never be able to follow this film because it requires a knowledge of the Reformation, the European monarchies and the specific tensions among them, and a familiarity with the power players of that period. You sound like a knee-jerk snob, I am sorry to say.

Molly Lambert, writing for Grantland, makes a nice connection between the Peggy Lee song and the below quote from Thomas Mann, on which the song is apparently based.

“Do you know, my dear sir, what disillusionment is?” he asked in low, urgent tones, both hands leaning on his stick. “Not a miscarriage in small, unimportant matters, but the great and general disappointment which everything, all of life, has in store?”

—"Disillusionment”

Something tells me there will NOT be an ending tied up neatly with a bow like Breaking Bad. I don't want a neat ending.

Senator Feinstein has unmitigated gall and hutzpah in her comments to Mr. Netanyahu.
Mr. Netanyahu has his job to do. Perhaps Senator Feinstein might have noticed that there are no voices in Israel supporting this deal, but rather only discussions as how to cope with it. Across the political board it is considered bad and problematical at best.
Just as she demands respect for her president, so she should have a minimum amount of respect for the Prime Minister of another country.

Olympia Diner? Really? Good pick-up!

Did anyone else think the paper cup Don doused his cigarette in during the opening scene (I think it was) looked familiar, like it had Greek design? Someone said it was a widely sold coffee machine cup from years ago.

These subtle allusions is one of the things that makes MM great.

but it's such a good story! For want of a healthy baby boy and a divorce- heads rolled, and there was deceit, lies, manipulation, religious upheaval, the Pilgrmage of Grace, downfall of a cardinal...no wonder we love it!

yeah, even re-watching the first 7 episodes on DVD, the arc about Megan and Don's marriage didn't make sense.  First she says, "This is how it ends," then with no explanation she's trying everything she can to keep Don: making him jealous, a three-way.  Then it's over on the phone.  Seemed like they must have had to edit out the expository connecting tissue for time's sake.

The actress hasn't appeared on MM before (at least not according to IMDB), but Esteban's suggestion of a sister (did he have a sister or just the one brother, now dead?) would probably be too soapy.  Maybe she is a modern Mildred Pierce, as Roger called her.  Is Don a modern male Mildred Pierce?
